I would like to hear everyones thoughts on the topic.  Your point about AT's
is well taken.

To my way of thinking, flawed though it might be, a unit describes one
scenario of one behavior.  For example, if we're talking about an ordering
system, a specified product might exist in a number of states, onhand and
not committed, on hand but committed, on order (imminent arrival), on order
(protracted arrival), out of stock at the supplier (undetermined
availability) or perhaps even never available again.  A customer wanting to
order that product might have patterned responses for each of these states.
If the task at hand is to develop a system that will automate the response
to a customer placing an order for this item, each possible state and
outcome combination constitutes a unit.  Each test case contributing its
behavioral rules to the design.

Ok, I've said my bit beat it up.

Regards,

-----Original Message-----
From: Jason Rogers [mailto:jason.rogers@...]
Sent: Tuesday, July 17, 2001 6:57 PM
To: 'junit@yahoogroups.com'
Subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?


I don't think that was the point.  The point was that Matthew (& co.) are
using JUnit for both UTs and ATs (FTs).  JUnit is actually very good for
some types of ATs because it is such a well designed automated testing
framework.  They aren't violating any premises, for as Matthew said they are
using it for UTs in the way it was meant.  But, if it happens to work for
their ATs, why not use it?

If you would still like to get into the debate of what is a "UNIT" though,
feel free.

-Jason

subject: RE: [junit] Why doesn't JUnit count asserts?
